newsitem.title: UK: Eurotunnel seen winning battle for business.
newsitem.headline: Eurotunnel seen winning battle for business.

text.p: Anglo-French cross-Channel operator Eurotunnel Plc was locked in talks with banks over its debts on Monday but analysts say it is winning its battle for business with the ferry companies.

Eurotunnel has seen its market share soar to 45 percent of the cross-Channel market since slashing prices for its Le Shuttle services in May. Analysts say it is set to raise that share further in 1997.
In its bid to secure the position of market leader, Eurotunnel ignited a new and more vicious price war, reducing economy vehicle fares through the tunnel by more than 50 percent earlier this year.

Passenger numbers were also boosted by a changeover in ownership of the British arm of the Eurostar passenger trains. This has marketed the service more aggressively as an alternative not only to ferries but also to short-haul continental flights.
The moves led to further haemorrhaging of sales at the ferry operators, with casualties including Peninsular and Oriental Steam Navigation Co (P&O) and Sweden's Stena.

Eurotunnel shares were suspended on Monday. A source in Paris close to the discussions said negotiations with banks over the firm's huge $14 billion debts were advancing and the positions getting closer.
Analysts say Eurotunnel's marketing strategy had been a success and expect further gains in market share next year.
Michael Cohen, analyst at Salomon Brothers, said: "I think we may see a further improvement -- perhaps close to 60 percent. But Eurotunnel will have to reach a balance on sales and prices."

Selwyn Jones, analyst at Credit Lyonnais Laing, agreed that although Eurotunnel could edge volumes a little higher, it would have to raise prices, too, as the current bargain-basement level was unsustainable.
"Prices cannot possibly go on at this level," he said. "The cross-Channel market of 1997 will be very different to 1996. Prices at Eurotunnel and the ferry companies will have to move higher."
But he added that the tunnel operator was unlikely to restore fares to the full 1995 level and might instead seek a rate between this and 1996 price-war levels.
Ferry companies have said they are looking at link-ups to cut excess capacity and allow room for higher prices.

The price war has seriously eroded results at big companies such as P&O and Stena, leading to calls for the freedom to establish alliances. Last week, Belgian state-owned group RMT said it would pull out of the Channel market completely.
Jones said the prospect of a ferry alliance was "no threat (to Eurotunnel) in the short term".
Cohen said the ferry companies had no choice but to link up, commenting: "The tunnel is there and they can't change its effect." A link-up is an inevitable prospect, he added.
In a related move, P&O is to buy out Dutch partner Nedlloyd's 50 percent stake in North Sea Ferries, which operates large passenger and freight ferries between Britain and the Netherlands.
